pr_title: GithubAction to manually start a release (#309)

timeline.message:
GithubAction to manually start a release (#309)

Adding possibility to manually trigger a release with a
workflow dispatch from GitHub Actions instead of a 
wandering tag.

closes: #309

GithubAction to manually start a release (#309)

updating documentation

timeline.bodyText: I think "releaseTrigger" should also be removed from the other workflows.
timeline.author: beatngu13

timeline.bodyText: No "releaseTrigger" anymore, so I guess this is useless now since there will be no other build(s) to wait for? At least if I get this right … anyhow, I think this is fine. master has already been built and should be fine.
timeline.author: beatngu13
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -2,18 +2,14 @@

 on:
-  create:
-    tags:
-      - 'releaseTrigger'
+  workflow_dispatch:
 
 jobs:
   deploy:
     runs-on: ubuntu-latest
     name: releasing

-        with:
-          ref: master

replies.bodyText: @aepfli sorry if I was imprecise, what I actually wanted to ask: shall we remove this step since there is no other build to wait for? What's your say on that?
replies.author: beatngu13

replies.bodyText: i would leave it actually, because theoretically, somebody could hit release on master branch, although all the checks are not finished.
replies.author: aepfli

timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -299,7 +299,7 @@ JUnit Pioneer uses [Shipkit](http://shipkit.org/) and [GitHub Actions](https://g
 Instead, releases must be triggered manually:
 
 1. make sure that the file [`version-properties`](version.properties) defines the correct version (see next section)
-2. push a tag `releaseTrigger` to `master`
+2. trigger the [`Release` GitHub Action](https://github.com/junit-pioneer/junit-pioneer/actions?query=workflow%3ARelease) manually for the master branch.
 
 GitHub Actions will then tell Shipkit to do its thing and afterwards delete the tag.
 The tag is always deleted, even if the release fails, so it is easy to trigger another one.
